Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Robotic-Assisted Versus Conventional Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Sample size calculation assumed a 5-point difference in the Knee Society score with 99% power, requiring 628 patients per group.

Participants.evidence: this trial included 1406 eligible patients at a single center.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomized to receive either robotic-assisted TKA (700 patients, 750 knees) or conventional TKA (706 patients, 766 knees).

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare robotic-assisted total knee arthroplasty (TKA) with conventional TKA in terms of long-term functional outcomes, radiographic parameters, survivorship, and complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Knee Society score, assessed preoperatively and at a mean follow-up of 13 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: this trial included 1406 eligible patients at a single center.

Number_Analysed.evidence: At follow-up, 674 patients in each group were analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant differences were found in Knee Society scores (robotic: 93 ± 5, conventional: 92 ± 6; p = 0.321)

Harms.evidence: Complications were comparable, with 2% of knees in each group experiencing superficial infections.
